name: Min/Max Druid " Bear form" build? Possibility?
author: Z0RnN

Best would be when i finally unlock dragon shape, i can safely ignore it. 

Best reagards, Z0RnN , Sweden

posts.author: Grimnir
posts.content:
Just make it like the dragon builds. It's all the same stuff that goes around.

Sent fra min SM-G950F via Tapatalk

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
Shifter forms and Elemental Shape are better than Wild Shape in almost all respects, so in terms of powerbuilding you would be better off focusing on a different form. However in the past I've played niche Wild Shape builds for the sake of playing a niche Wild Shape build, so I have a few suggestions. Note that almost all of them can be improved by focusing on a different form.

Dru/Ass DC assassin (even more useless in EE than it was in 1.69).
Dru/Bard/PM AC tank.
Dru/BG smiter.
Dru/CoT smiter.
Dru/Monk/Figh stunner.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Hello and welcome Z0RnN, I can see this is your first post to the ECB forum!

Grimnir is correct in that Dragon Shape is much more powerful in combat, however Dragon Shape suffers problems going through standard doorways, and can only be used 3x / day which can be a problem in environments which are rest restricted. 

Grimnir is also correct in that any Druid/Dragon Shape build you can play the build in bear form anyway.

Even if Dragon Shape/Elder Elemental Form is more powerful, I still enjoy playing my druids in bear form. 

For some reason they have a certain personality that is undeniable magnetic.


This is from a forum post I made in the World of Greyhawk Tapatalk Forum 6 months ago

Its particularly cute to watch them try to loot chests, pick up items, even open locks and disable traps! I hear its commonplace in countries like Canada for bears to break into cars for that delicious peanut butter sandwich...

Anyway, you are asking for a min-maxed druid bear form. This is my thoughts from a technical standpoint. 

1. Dire Bear form -> at least Druid 12, infinite wild shape is even better with Druid 22

2. At least one level of Monk, for Monk UBAB for bears + Flurry of Blows which essentially doubles your attacks, Evasion, Wisdom AC, Monk Speed/Improved Knockdown (if you go that far)

3. Buffs / Item bonuses. There is a lot to consider here. Only magical properties from Helmet/Armor/Shield transfer. Only the maximum bonus transfers (ie a +4 AC armor and +2 AC shield will transfer to +4 deflection AC). Everything else has to come from spell buffs (ie. Druid spells), UMD, Items or teammates.
Spoilera. Str with Bull's Strength / Blood Frenzy / Aura of Vitality spells + Str bonuses on helmet/armor/shield c. Con with Blood Frenzy / Aura of Vitality,  Bonuses on helmet/armor/shield, Endurance from potions/scrolls with UMD e. Deflection AC from equipped items, brooch of shielding (+4 AC) g. Dodge and other AC -> Mage Armor cast from UMD or a teammate would give you least +2 AC (armor, dodge) maybe a bit more, also potentially Divine Shield i. Mind immunity -> from items, clarity potions, lesser mind blank/mind blank scrolls with UMD k. Freedom -> Freedom of movement spell from druid m. Divine Might/Divine Shield to add divine damage to attacks, or add dodge AC -> due to alignment restrictions the best way to access this is probably Cleric, which has the side effect of giving you an extra spellbook, but you will lose access to the Thieves Hood which may or may be important in your environment or your discipline score. Blackguard or Paladin will require 3 levels of investment and alignment shifting if you take one level of monk as well.
4. Stats -> only your Intelligence, Wisdom and Charisma scores transfer when you turn into bear form, so your Strength, Dexterity and Constitution stats shouldn't be your focus with starting stats or leveling.

Anyway have a look at the technical details, and if wanted to tell us more about what you want in the build for example do you want to be able to use divine might for divine damage, post a reply and maybe I can flesh something out.

Also let me know if you want dragon shape or not, you can still play dragon shape builds but it might be reasonable to drop the idea of divine damage with your bear with the tremendous investment required to obtain dragon shape.

And can you remind us the environment you plan to play this in and what is the highest level you expect to achieve in this environment.

posts.author: Yunim
posts.content:
If you're happy to play at level 40 without levelling up from level 1 then I'd go with a Dru12/Pal3/CoT25 bear smiter.
This is a very gimmicky build, combining Wild Shape with Divine Wrath and Smite Evil, but it's one of the best bear builds that can be made. It has 4 shifts per day, 3 smites per day, and 1 Divine Wrath per day. It also requires two alignment changes (Lawful Neutral / Neutral Good to Lawful Good and back).

The build has high HP, extremely high saves, and immunities to disease, fear, and poison.
Damage is surprisingly decent, although it requires +11 STR and +12 CHA to max out which is hard to achieve with vanilla item merging. With +11 STR, +12 CHA, Divine Might, and Divine Wrath, the damage is 1d8 + 16 (+ 308 Smite Evil) Physical + 26 Divine. Minimum smite damage is 325 Physical + 26 Divine, minimum smite critical damage is 650 Physical + 52 Divine. The Divine damage ignores DI/DR, so even the toughest enemies will take 26 damage per hit.

The main problems are low AB (and no real way to improve it in vanilla NWN), low AC, your attacks are +0 for DR purposes, and you're a shifter. Divine Wrath gives +11 AB but it's a once per day ability and it only lasts for 15 rounds. The only other way to increase your AB in vanilla NWN is through spells, since weapons don't merge for unarmed forms. Casting Stoneskin on yourself before shifting will make your attacks count as +5 for DR purposes, but once it wears off they will be back to +0 attacks.

Called Shot can be swapped for another feat such as Improved Critical: Scimitar if you want a different pre-epic feat.

I didn't bother with the skill progression since it's just a rough draft, but you can max Discipline, Spellcraft, Tumble, put ranks into skills that require training, and almost max another skill such as Spot.

===

Class: Druid 12 / Paladin 3 / Champion Of Torm 25
Race: Human
Alignment: Lawful Good / Lawful Neutral / Neutral Good (requires 2 alignment changes)
Playability: 40 PvM / 40 PvP

STR: 14
DEX: 8
CON: 8
WIS: 14 (16)
INT: 10
CHA: 18 (28)

01: Druid(1): Blind Fight, Power Attack
02: Druid(2)
03: Druid(3): Weapon Focus: Scimitar
04: Paladin(1): CHA+1, (CHA=19), *Alignment Change*
05: Paladin(2)
06: Paladin(3): Divine Might
07: Druid(4): *Alignment Change*
08: Druid(5): CHA+1, (CHA=20)
09: Druid(6): Knockdown
10: Druid(7)
11: Druid(8)
12: Druid(9): CHA+1, Improved Critical: Unarmed, (CHA=21)
13: Druid(10)
14: Champion of Torm(1)
15: Champion of Torm(2): Toughness, Called Shot
16: Champion of Torm(3): CHA+1, (CHA=22)
17: Champion of Torm(4): Improved Power Attack
18: Champion of Torm(5): Extra Smiting
19: Druid(11)
20: Druid(12): CHA+1, (CHA=23)
21: Champion of Torm(6): Great Charisma I, Great Wisdom I, (WIS=15), (CHA=24)
22: Champion of Torm(7)
23: Champion of Torm(8): Epic Prowess
24: Champion of Torm(9): CHA+1, Great Smite I, (CHA=25)
25: Champion of Torm(10): Great Smite II
26: Champion of Torm(11)
27: Champion of Torm(12): Great Smite III
28: Champion of Torm(13): WIS+1, (WIS=16)
29: Champion of Torm(14): Great Smite IV
30: Champion of Torm(15): Great Smite V
31: Champion of Torm(16)
32: Champion of Torm(17): CHA+1, (CHA=26)
33: Champion of Torm(18): Great Smite VI, Great Smite VII
34: Champion of Torm(19)
35: Champion of Torm(20)
36: Champion of Torm(21): CHA+1, Great Smite VIII, (CHA=27)
37: Champion of Torm(22): Great Smite IX
38: Champion of Torm(23)
39: Champion of Torm(24): Great Smite X
40: Champion of Torm(25): CHA+1, (CHA=28)

===

Naked Stats
Hitpoints: 376
Skillpoints: 159
Saving Throws (Fortitude/Will/Reflex): 45/44/39
Saving Throw bonuses: Fear: +2
BAB: 27
AB (max, naked): 31 (melee), 27 (ranged)
AC (naked/mundane armor/shield only): 9/20
Spell Casting: Druid(6)
Alignment Changes: 2

Buffed Stats (While shifted, assuming that you have +11 STR, +11 CON, +12 CHA, one +5 AC item, and Haste)
AB: 27 (BAB) + 16 (STR) + 1 (Feats) - 1 (Size) = +43 (+54 with Divine Wrath) (+58/+69 when smiting)
AC: 10 (Base) + 1 (DEX) + 4 (Tumble) + 5 (AC Bonus) + 5 (Shape Dodge Bonus) + 4 (Barkskin) + 4 (Haste) - 1 (Size) = 32
HP: 376 (Base) + 400 (CON) + 40 (Feats) = 816
Fortitude: 25 (Base) + 10 (CON) + 15 (CHA) + 12 (CoT Bonus) = 62 (70 with Divine Wrath)
Reflex: 19 (Base) + 1 (DEX) + 15 (CHA) + 12 (CoT Bonus) = 47 (55 with Divine Wrath)
Will: 20 (Base) + 3 (WIS) + 15 (CHA) + 12 (CoT Bonus) = 50 (58 with Divine Wrath)

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Ahhh I've been ninja'ed by you Z0RnN! In case you don't know what that means feel free to ask Stag :) but its pointless to ask Mick because he's usually the Ninja'er (if such a term exists?)

I would propose a simple druid / monk / champion of torm build if that is the case.

You will get dire bear form right from the get go at level 15.

You will also notice it has maxed stealth (a stealthy bear), maxed tumble (a ballerina bear), maxed discipline (boxer bear), maxed spellcraft (arcane bear) and maxed persuasion (persuasive bear).

I have avoided building for maximum level 40 power so you can enjoy 'bear power' from the get go. I took knockdown and improved knockdown as feats so you can enjoy them earlier. 

Hate to be the bearer of bad news... but hope you find it bearable... I mean bear with me... just getting my bearings... 

The Z0RnN's Bear Build (Druid 27/Monk 5/CoT 8)


Image source: https://punpedia.org/bear-puns/

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
The best 'bear' pieces of equipment are good pieces of armor, shield or helmet.
These item slots are the only ones which transfer magical properties.
There are more details on this in the NWN Wiki: Polymorph

Beyond that you will need to buff yourself with spells or items before you transform into a  bear.
The only item you can use when you are transformed are potions.

Thats why I included extend spell, in case you needed a spell such as bull's strength to last a long time.

And solid point on the time, compassion thing etc... such values are quite undervalued in our world

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hi ZORnN. Your alignment would be Lawful Neutral. Monks have to be Lawful, Druids have to be Neutral, and CoT has to be non-Evil.

As far as the ninja-ing goes, the bear necessities are that it's when someone else posts while you're composing your own post, so it takes you somewhat by surprise. I tend to type slowly, so suffer from ninja visitations more than most (I try to provide them with tea and biscuits to keep them friendly).

Cheers

EDIT: There's a prime example - Orion's just ninja'd me!

Oh, and you asked about why we don't include gear/kit. That's mostly because what's available will vary from module to module and from persistent world to persistent world, and we try to offer the best builds we can regardless of environment, unless there are specifics given to us at the Build Request point.

That ain't no bear!

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Dear Z0RnN
You've visited the an elite NWN character building skill training facility for players, and I have been whipped into shape very solidly for several months by the likes of Valerfor, Mick Dagger, Stag, Empyre65, and I have learned much.

Any build posted should be expected to receive critique. Any critique posted should expect also to receive critique. Sometimes the critique of the critique must be critiqued. For it is through such a process we grow and learn, approached with an open mind, devoid of defensiveness - the focus being what is best for the player in the circumstances provided to achieve their goals...

Characters take quite a long time to play and progress. If you are like me I like things 'perfected' as much as possible before I start playing a build. The worst thing is getting halfway and realising you did something very ineffective with the starting stats or feats or whatever and start from scratch...

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
I designed it so K0RnN can have both dire bear form and improved knockdown at level 15, which he stated was the highest level he could create a character on the Nintendo Switch. Then import the character into the original campaign and destroy the enemies of Neverwinter. Because he will be level 15 in an area designed for levels 3 onwards, it will be quite some time before he gains further levels, so I wanted him to have all the good stuff immediately which was his goal - play a devastating killer bear!

If he was playing on a standard computer he could easily install a character creator like PGCC and insert a character of level 40 and in that situation monk 6 is more optimal.

Horses for courses as they say. If he wasn't playing on Nintendo Switch and starting the OC at 15 you would be correct.

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content: Oh, I was only spit-balling here Orion - it wasn't intended as an actual suggestion: sorry 'bout that. I don't pretend to feel qualified to comment on druid builds in any case - never played one, never built one.

posts.author: Orion
posts.content:
Stagmeister wrote: ↑
Jan 08, 2020
Oh, I was only spit-balling here Orion - it wasn't intended as an actual suggestion: sorry 'bout that. I don't pretend to feel qualified to comment on druid builds in any case - never played one, never built one.
Agree with conloach by the way, that Monk 5 class split makes you want to reach for that additional monk level to get to 6... and a very lovely analogy. 

I must confess before Christmas I have started calorie counting, and when I realise that cookie is 100 calories and would require 1hr of walking to burn off the energy in it, its far less attractive to add to my energy record for the day then say, 20 blueberries which is close to 30. 

Likewise Monk 6 could delay knockdown/improved knockdown to save Z0RnN two pre-epic feats you actually don't need to make the build playable, more nice stuff like extra saves / spell foci / zen archery but not essential to Z0RnN's needs. Monk 9 might be kinder as Stag has suggested but starting at level 15 the bear form wouldn't be as strong. 

And spit-balling is always appreciated :) 

That aside I believe you are underselling your skills somewhat here Stag, you have spent a few years studying the process of optimising builds and have suggested a number of improvements to my own, knowing the class is one thing from a gameplay perspective, but optimising stuff is another, and if the OP's writes the goals desired, within your limits I'm sure you can make useful commentary when it feels right

posts.author: Knight_oflimbo
posts.content:
Druid 12/monk 2/Dwarven defender 26

Race: Dorf

Alignment: LN

Stats
Level ups go into Con until 22, then goes into wisdom

8 STR
14 Dex
18 Con
14 int
15 wis
8 Cha

1: Druid , dodge
2: Druid
3: Druid, toughness
4: Druid
5: Druid
6: druid, disarm
7: druid
8: druid:
9: druid:  blind fight
10: druid
11 druid
12: druid, IC: unarmed, dire bear
13: dwd
14: dwd
15: dwd: imp disarm
16: dwd
17: dwd
18: dwd: kd
18-40: take 2 more monk levels for tumble dump at 22/27/32/37, rest goes into dwd

Feats: on general feat level, take epic prowess and  great wisdom, on dwd bonus feats, take Epic damage resist, armored skin.


AC: 15 base+ 8 tumble + 2 armor skin + 9?wisdom+4 def stance = 38 before items and buffs. Barkskin, +5 whatever AC item , wisdom and dex buffs should bring this up to low 50s.

Ab: 26 base + 10 STR +  1 EP + 4? From improved disarm= 41 base.

Damage: 1d8+10?

If they somehow hit you, 27/- DR and probably 600+ HP.

Your offense is super ass, especially when you are trying to punch through DR, but you shouldn't be dying and you can attack really fast.

If all else fails, unshift into human form and punch the meat off of them with gloves.
